skill.name: SQLAlchemy 2.0+
skill.description: Modern async ORM with type-safe models and efficient queries
skill.summary: Modern async ORM with type-safe models and efficient queries
skill.author: bossjones

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing SQLAlchemy usage examples. All static findings were false positives from pattern matching errors. No executable code or security risks detected.

content.user_title: Build async database applications with SQLAlchemy
content.value_statement: SQLAlchemy 2.0+ provides modern async database operations with type safety. Build scalable APIs and services with efficient ORM patterns and native Python type hints.
actual_capabilities: Create async database models with type annotations
Execute CRUD operations with async/await syntax
Integrate with FastAPI using dependency injection
limitations: Async patterns differ from sync SQLAlchemy

use_cases.title: Build REST API with database
use_cases.description: Create FastAPI endpoints with async database operations using SQLAlchemy models and sessions.

use_cases.title: Async data processing pipelines
use_cases.description: Build efficient data ingestion and processing systems with async database connections.

use_cases.title: Type-safe database models
use_cases.description: Design database schemas with Python type hints and automatic validation.

prompt_templates.title: Create User Model
prompt_templates.scenario: Define a user model with email and password
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a SQLAlchemy User model with id, email, password_hash, and created_at fields using the new 2.0 syntax with Mapped types

prompt_templates.title: Async CRUD Operations
prompt_templates.prompt: Write async functions for creating, reading, updating, and deleting users using SQLAlchemy async sessions

prompt_templates.title: Database Relationships
prompt_templates.prompt: Extend the User model to have a one-to-many relationship with a Post model, including the Post model definition

prompt_templates.title: Complex Queries
prompt_templates.prompt: Write an async function that queries users with optional filters for name and email using SQLAlchemy select

output_examples.input: Create a SQLAlchemy model for a blog post with title, content, author relationship, and timestamps
output: ‚úì Created Post model with Mapped column types
‚úì Added author relationship with User model

best_practices: Use async_sessionmaker for creating session factories
Always use context managers for session handling
Add indexes to frequently queried columns
anti_patterns: Never use sync SQLAlchemy in async applications
Avoid N+1 queries by using selectinload
Don't keep sessions open longer than necessary

faq.question: What's the difference between sync and async SQLAlchemy?
faq.answer: Async SQLAlchemy uses async drivers and await syntax for non-blocking database operations.

faq.question: Which databases are supported?
faq.answer: PostgreSQL (asyncpg), SQLite (aiosqlite), and MySQL (aiomysql) with their async drivers.

faq.question: How do I handle database migrations?
faq.answer: Use Alembic with async support to generate and apply schema migrations.

faq.question: Can I use this with FastAPI?
faq.answer: Yes, use dependency injection to provide async sessions to your endpoints.

faq.question: What's the benefit of type annotations?
faq.answer: Type hints provide better IDE support, autocompletion, and catch errors early.

faq.question: How do I debug SQL queries?
faq.answer: Enable SQL echo on your engine to see generated SQL statements in the console.
